awd_titl_txt: Transforming Outdoor Places into Learning Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops and examines place-based learning using mobile augmented reality experiences for rural families where museums and science centers are scarce yet where natural resources are rich with outdoor trails, parks, and forestlands. The collaborative research team, with members from rural libraries, outdoor learning centers, learning scientists at Penn State University, and rural communities in Pennsylvania, will develop augmented reality and mobile learning resources for families and children aged from 4 to 12. The goal is to help people see what is not visible in real-time in order to learn about life and earth sciences based on local watersheds, trees, and seasonal cycles that are familiar and relevant to rural communities. To accomplish this goal, the project team will create scientifically meaningful experiences for rural families and children in their out-of-school time through three iterations of research and design. Although there is evidence that augmented reality can support learning, little empirical research has been conducted to determine what makes one type of augmented learning experience more effective than others in outdoor learning spaces. This project will produce research findings on the utility of augmented reality for science learning with families and youths outdoors. This Innovations in Development project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants

Through a four-year design-based research study, researchers will investigate three research questions. (1) How can outdoor learning experiences be enhanced with augmented reality and digital resources in ways that make science more visible and interesting?; (2) How do different forms of augmentations on trails and in gardens support science learning? 3) What social roles do children and parents play in supporting each other's science learning and connections to rural communities? Data collection includes video-recordings of children and families in the outdoors, learning analytics of people's behavior, and interviews with rural families. The project's research design will allow for the development of theory, which supports rural families learning science within and about their communities. At the end of the project, the team will offer generalizable design principles for technologically-enhanced informal learning for outdoor displays, gardens, and trails.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The SPACES research and development project created five interactive, mobile learning applications (apps) for rural families to use in the outdoors. The apps employed augmented reality (AR) to layer digital resources (i.e., animations, AR filters, photos) onto outdoor places through the screens of mobile devices. The SPACES project worked with 256 families (405 adults and 491 children), who were primarily from rural counties in Pennsylvania. Families used these apps to learn science as they walked through an arboretum, children's garden, environmental center, and their own backyards. 

The team designed five mobile apps: Cave Explorers, Arboretum Pollinator Explorers (farms and gardens), Shaver's Creek Pollinator Explorers (meadows and forests), Backyard Explorers, and Time Explorers. The five apps shared four common design features to support family science learning: (1) AR filters or animations for visualizing complex concepts; (2) digital educational resources tied to specific place elements;  (3) photo capture tools to channel observations of key scientific phenomena; and (4) question prompts to promote conversations around families' prior knowledge, shared memories, and experiences in rural locations.  

Figures 1-5 provide screen captures from the five apps. 

Team leads were learning scientists from Penn State University College of Education. Other collaborators were ecologists and pollinator scientists from the Center for Pollinator Research, Rockman et al Cooperative (evaluators), and educators from the Arboretum at Penn State and Shaver's Creek Environmental Center. The development team included a graphic artist and computer programmers from the Teaching and Learning with Technology and the Center for Immersive Experiences. 

 

Findings

 

  1. Families participating in the team's family-centered, outdoor mobile learning experiences demonstrated increased science knowledge. The team's research findings showed that families had statistically significant gains in their science knowledge after using the SPACES apps, with medium to large effect sizes. These findings support using mobile apps designed for outdoor science learning as effective tools to increase families' science knowledge in short out-of-school learning experiences. Given that many rural communities are under-resourced with informal education institutions, this work suggests that custom, place-based mobile apps are a productive way to support science learning for small-town agricultural or woodland communities. 

  2. The mobile AR app design enhanced families' engagement with scientific concepts by making invisible phenomena visible. Each of the five mobile apps used AR filters or animations to help visualize science concepts that would be impossible to see without technological assistance, enhancing families' understanding of their communities. For instance, AR animations in the Cave Explorers app simulated the formation of cave columns and dripping water. This visualization helped families grasp the geological processes involved in cave formation -- processes that occur over vast timescales and are not readily observable in real-time. The Bee Vision feature in the Backyard Explorers app allowed families to see how bees see the world, which helped them notice the colors and patterns that attract pollinators. In the Pollinator Explorers app, a simulated visualization revealed potential bee nests hidden within real logs at the nature center, creating an immersive experience that blurred the boundaries between the digital and physical, resulting in high levels of science learning and interest.

  3. The mobile apps design supported families' scientific observations by encouraging them to notice scientifically relevant features and to connect those features to related scientific concepts. The apps structured families' observations by providing checklists, photo annotation tools, guiding questions, and prompts. Activities like photo-taking and observation checklists effectively supported families' noticing of scientific phenomena and the development of their observational practices. For instance, the Backyard Explorers app incorporated photo-taking activities and checklists prompting families to document key characteristics of pollinators and flowers. The app asked families to take photos of pollinators and flowers and answer yes and no questions about their observations. This structured approach fostered more discipline-specific noticing related to bee habitat. Similarly, the Time Explorers app, designed to explore geological time, prompted families to observe and discuss specific landscape features, fostering deeper engagement with the region's geological history.

  4. The mobile apps supported place-based family learning by encouraging them to connect with their local outdoor settings and communities. The mobile apps encouraged the exploration of outdoor spaces that were familiar to families, prompting them to talk with each other about meaningful science phenomena in their yards, communities, and parks. Most apps utilized GPS-triggered content that was deployed at specific public locations such as the partnering arboretum and nature center. For instance, the Time Explorers app utilized GPS to guide families on a geological time walk through a children's garden to have conversations about the interactions of water and land within their community. Families built knowledge about how the Appalachian landscape changed over time, connecting information from different learning sites in a Children's Garden. The team also developed a location-independent app (Backyard Explorers) that can be deployed anywhere, in order to expand opportunities for families to talk about pollinators in their neighborhoods.
